07299187-b81e-4db7-a422-a159474cbb59.txt.LLM_question: Who was the first President of South Africa after the end of apartheid?
07299187-b81e-4db7-a422-a159474cbb59.txt.LLM_answer: The first President of South Africa after the end of apartheid was Nelson Mandela [1]. In an interview with Fortune magazine in 1993, Mandela discussed his plans for the economy and his vision for the future of South Africa [1]. He emphasized the importance of foreign investment and creating jobs for the people of South Africa, stating that "any strategy that will achieve that objective, I would support" [1]. Mandela's leadership marked a significant turning point in South African history, as he worked to rebuild the country and promote reconciliation after the end of apartheid.
07299187-b81e-4db7-a422-a159474cbb59.txt.LLM_query: Who was Nelson Mandela's predecessor or successor in that role?

d96f4388-dafe-4787-9c3c-c85f4781dfb7.text: "Editor's note: This interview with prisoner-turned South African President Nelson Mandela conducted by our former editor Marshall Loeb was first published in the July 12, 1993 issue of Fortune. Interview by Marshall Loeb; reporter associate Jane Furth July 12, 1993. A NEW ERA IS DAWNING in relations between the U.S. and South Africa. Full- scale trade and investment will soon resume, as Nelson Mandela calls for an end to all sanctions. Almost certainly, the charismatic leader of the African National Congress will become the first black President of his country after the first truly universal elections are held next spring. On the eve of his visit to the U.S. to receive the Liberty Medal, Mandela was vigorous and erect despite having spent 27 of his 74 years in South African prisons. He talked in Johannesburg with FORTUNE managing editor Marshall Loeb about the future he foresees for South Africa's economy and the important role foreign business will play. Excerpts: Q: What are your plans for the economy

metadata.title: Mandela reaches out to business

eb1980e6-3e5a-4374-93fd-09984f1e80d7.text: We believe in a mixed economy, which is based on private enterprise and which would allow intervention by the state where it is suitable -- where it is in the interest of the country and its people. In the past you have been called a socialist. Now you seem to be moving to the center. Can you describe your position today?  I am neither a capitalist nor a socialist. I am a pragmatist. All that I want is that the living standards of our people be raised. Any strategy that will achieve that objective, I would support.\nThis story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/article/mandela-reaches-out-to-business-fortune-1993/>

metadata.title: Mandela reaches out to business

d2927758-7b84-4317-b033-fbdbe9ae7e01.text: A: We should look into two areas: the development of a manufacturing base and the development of an infrastructure in the country. Our economy has underperformed since 1975. Growth has been less than the growth of the population. Naturally we require foreign investment. I would not restrict it to any particular kind of company. What we are primarily interested in is development that creates opportunities for employment, because 48% of our people are unemployed. And we are therefore very keen for foreign companies to invest in such a way that there will be a creation of jobs for our people, a generation of wealth. All foreign companies that invest would be guaranteed against expropriation and nationalization. They will be able to recover their profits and dividends -- all of them. We are guaranteeing every foreign company that invests in our country. Would it be fair and accurate to have a headline in FORTUNE read: MANDELA WELCOMES FOREIGN INVESTMENT?

metadata.title: Mandela reaches out to business

ae30edc9-c2e0-4ec2-86dd-bcf96c032e60.text: "We will have to look into that. Any scheme that will empower blacks will be welcomed

metadata.title: The ANC party that freed South Africa from apartheid loses its 30-year majority, signaling first-ever coalition government to come

c6e8e04f-54a5-43a0-8cb5-f787ac017187.text:
More than 50 parties <https://apnews.com/article/south-africa-election-ramaphosa-anc-parties-44187959a44ddaddadd0ad4b23bebd83> contested the election, many of them winning tiny shares, but the three main opposition parties appear to be the most obvious for the ANC to approach <https://apnews.com/article/south-africa-election-vote-explainer-anc-ramaphosa-0e7600dc16bd51e3b6faa6cef6455e24>.

Electoral commission Chairman Mosotho Moepya said it was a time for everyone to keep calm “and for leaders to lead and for voices of reason to continue to prevail.”

"This is a moment we need to manage and manage well," he said.

Steenhuisen said his party is open to discussions with the ANC, as did Malema. The MK Party said one of their conditions for any agreement was that Ramaphosa is removed as ANC leader and president. That underlined the fierce personal political battle between Zuma, who resigned as South African president under a cloud of corruption allegations in 2018, and Ramaphosa, who replaced him.

metadata.title: The ANC party that freed South Africa from apartheid loses its 30-year majority, signaling first-ever coalition government to come

9dbab576-f591-4602-9821-ddc6967eaa25.text: "The African National Congress <https://apnews.com/article/south-africa-election-anc-decline-cf154312e3dc5c1b5ee615b82ba0c080> party lost its parliamentary majority in a historic election result Saturday that puts South Africa on a new political path for the first time since the end of the apartheid system of white minority rule 30 years ago.\n\nWith more than 99% of votes counted

metadata.title: The ANC party that freed South Africa from apartheid loses its 30-year majority, signaling first-ever coalition government to come

667b33c6-b363-4d19-bcd3-88293cbbfa2b.text:
“We are willing to negotiate with the ANC, but not the ANC of Cyril Ramaphosa," MK Party spokesperson Nhlamulo Ndlela said.

MK and the far-left Economic Freedom Fighters <https://apnews.com/article/south-africa-election-opposition-eff-malema-ef4d87176b5b53e5768eac02fc9b0129> have called for parts of the economy to be nationalized.

The centrist Democratic Alliance <https://apnews.com/article/south-africa-elections-anc-democratic-alliance-3df5ca5aaf213349b8e929bc4408c69c>, or DA, is viewed as business-friendly. Analysts say an ANC-DA coalition would be more welcomed by foreign investors.

DA has been the most critical opposition party for years and doesn't share the ANC's pro-Russia and pro-China foreign policy. South Africa takes over the presidency of the Group of 20 industrialized and emerging-market nations next year.

An ANC-DA coalition "would be a marriage of two drunk people in Las Vegas. It will never work,” Gayton McKenzie, the leader of the smaller Patriotic Alliance party, told South African media.

2d22d5c8-15c2-4f61-b5cb-14833b0449e5.text: A day after dropping out of the race, while suffering from COVID-19, President Biden called into a rally at his campaign headquarters to support his successor Vice President Kamala Harris, “I know the news was hard, but it was the right thing to do. I know we made the right decision. I’ve been honored and humbled. The name has changed on the top of the ticket. I’m not going anywhere We still need to save this democracy. I will still be fully engaged, speaking out on the guns, childcare, bringing hostages home, getting the Gaza war to end. I have to keep our alliances together for our safety. I’ll be doing whatever Kamala asks me to do in addition.”\n\nWith Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi providing her timely endorsement <https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2024/07/22/kamala-harris-campaign-biden-drop-out/nancy-pelosi-endorsement-00170365> to Vice President Harris, it cannot go without notice that Pelosi herself modeled the passing of the torch to the next generation, with her seamless voluntary handoff to Hakeem Jeffries, providing her unique credibility on the challenges of succession.

metadata.title: Biden follows a long line of Western leaders who voluntarily surrendered power at the end of a ‘heroic journey,’ says the author of The Hero’s Farewell

b5e5badb-84e3-41d0-bc72-756d5ce2e839.txt.LLM_question: Who is the CEO of Tesla as of 2023?
b5e5badb-84e3-41d0-bc72-756d5ce2e839.txt.LLM_answer: As of 2023, Elon Musk is still the CEO of Tesla [3]. Despite some investors and critics calling for a change in leadership, Musk has maintained his position as CEO. In fact, some investors, like Gary Black of The Future Fund, believe that there is no one else who can fill Musk's shoes, and that the alternative to Musk as CEO is "just too hard to fathom" [1]. Additionally, Musk has taken steps to ensure that no one else can succeed him, having removed top lieutenants like Zach Kirkhorn and Drew Baglino, who were seen as potential successors [1].
b5e5badb-84e3-41d0-bc72-756d5ce2e839.txt.LLM_query: Is the CEO of Tesla still the same as of 2023?

a5f668fb-a0d8-4a6c-9ed7-872c6d3d817d.text:
“Given this, we’re not sure why shareholders would vote against the board,” warned sell-side analyst Alex Potter from Piper Sandler <https://fortune.com/company/piper-sandler/>. 

Like Potter, money manager Gary Black of The Future Fund, a longtime bull, summed <https://x.com/garyblack00/status/1798783611916964296> it up much more simply: “The alternative is just too hard to fathom.”

That’s partly because there does not seem to be anyone else the company can turn to. 

All talk of grooming a successor, first confirmed <https://fortune.com/2022/11/17/elon-musk-tesla-ceo-successor-board-directors-potential-candidates-james-murdoch/> back in November 2022, has ceased entirely over the past 12 months after Musk removed former finance chief Zach Kirkhorn and powertrain boss Drew Baglino—two top lieutenants best placed to run Tesla in his absence. 

With these moves, Musk has ensured that no one of his stature can fill his giant shoes.

Fierce headwinds for Tesla

metadata.title: Tesla shareholders’ vote on Elon Musk’s record $56 billion pay deal could be his ‘last stand’ as CEO, experts warn

dc3c29bb-af89-4ced-9d34-dd17366a1523.text:
Fierce headwinds for Tesla 

That’s tough luck for Musk’s detractors <https://fortune.com/2024/04/07/elon-musk-tesla-sales-ceo-compensation-twitter-fans/>, such as early Tesla investor and onetime board director Steve Westly <https://fortune.com/2024/06/06/former-tesla-board-member-says-he-wouldnt-vote-for-musk/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>, who otherwise would have the perfect opportunity to topple the CEO from his perch. 

Financially, the company has hit a brick wall <https://fortune.com/2024/03/23/elon-musk-tesla-q1-production-deliveries-earnings-growth/>.

metadata.title: Tesla shareholders’ vote on Elon Musk’s record $56 billion pay deal could be his ‘last stand’ as CEO, experts warn

bff66701-ed3b-4019-8243-b58ee69b2224.text: Tesla’s workforce already has endured dramatic transformation <https://fortune.com/2024/05/18/tesla-chair-robyn-denholm-ceo-elon-musk-pay-package-oversight-annual-meeting/> the last few years — the onetime Silicon Valley upstart with a maniacal vision on clean energy is now concentrated in Texas <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-04-01/elon-musk-boosts-headcount-by-86-at-tesla-tsla-site-anchoring-texas-empire> and fixated on other undertakings, including artificial intelligence <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-03-09/how-much-energy-do-ai-and-chatgpt-use-no-one-knows-for-sure> and robots <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-12-13/tesla-optimus-gen-2-new-video-shows-dancing-robot-better-movement-updates>.\n\nSome still with the company say Musk has sapped morale by prioritizing a robotaxi over a $25,000 electric vehicle. They also say a mission that had inspired legions of Musk acolytes has been muddied.

metadata.title: Elon Musk still hasn’t finished his 10% layoffs at Tesla and employees are ‘walking on eggshells every day’: ‘It’s hard to see the long game’

259c2d88-b57d-4066-955f-6a561844b788.text:
No longer undisputed as chief executive 

On the one hand, many investors felt Musk deserves every penny after he built an upstart carmaker teetering on bankruptcy into one of the most valuable companies in the world. On the other, the timing could be better, as some Tesla loyalists are beginning to question his leadership <https://fortune.com/2024/04/07/elon-musk-tesla-sales-ceo-compensation-twitter-fans/>.

Two of Musk’s top lieutenants left without explanation, the core car business is on the decline, mass firings appear have confused investors <https://fortune.com/2024/05/02/elon-musk-tesla-supercharger-headcount-sales-growth/> (and some have been reversed <https://fortune.com/2024/05/13/tesla-supercharger-workers-rehired-elon-musk-layoff-entire-team-max-dezegher/>) and the stock price has failed to hold onto gains for over three years.

There is also little guarantee that a successful vote won’t be challenged once more in the courts as a form of illegal corporate waste.

metadata.title: Tesla—which never buys ads—is buying ads to promote Elon Musk’s record $52 billion pay deal days before key shareholder vote

0e257fe5-9666-4559-ad76-d20ef59e98fc.text: Gerber Kawasaki CEO Ross Gerber <https://fortune.com/2022/12/21/tesla-twitter-investor-ross-gerber-says-elon-musk-not-suited-social-media-chief/>, who has called Musk an “absent CEO” and said Tesla needs to have a “real CEO <https://fortune.com/2024/03/15/tesla-cathie-wood-elon-musk-ceo-ross-gerber-shareholders-ark-invest/>,” noted that Musk deserves compensation but excoriated the board for what he deemed poor conduct. The “board of directors sucks, to be honest,” Gerber told CNBC. “They just stink. I’ve never seen such a bad board. It’s going to be written about in business schools for years to come to study what a horrendous board Tesla has.”\nTesla’s board chair Robyn Denholm said it was “absolute BS <https://fortune.com/2024/05/18/tesla-chair-robyn-denholm-ceo-elon-musk-pay-package-oversight-annual-meeting/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>” she wasn’t independent of Musk, as McCormick had suggested.

45e0fda7-524e-4b5c-a5ad-02bd7d2cc14e.text: The stock is, unsurprisingly, down slightly for the year, compared to the S&P 500’s 22% gain. As Fortune’s Geoff Colvin wrote last week, Tesla’s even been knocked out <https://fortune.com/2024/10/05/broadcom-tesla-magnificent-7-companies-market-cap/> of the so-called “Magnificent Seven”—America’s seven largest tech companies by market cap— by surging semiconductor and software giant Broadcom <https://fortune.com/company/broadcom/>. While Tesla’s stock sits roughly where it was four years ago, Broadcom’s is up about 290% over that time.\n\nMusk has not been sheepish about staking <https://fortune.com/2024/09/28/elon-musk-tesla-robotaxi-autonomous-self-driving-cars-robots-ai/> the company’s future on autonomous software. Currently, what Tesla calls “full self-driving” is considered a level two-plus autonomous product <https://www.simplyfleet.app/blog/levels-of-autonomous-vehicles>, per Goldstein.

54c605d3-0b7c-43db-9ad9-f77e53a4cac6.text: Many Tesla investors were willing to put up with CEO Elon Musk’s widely covered behavior—his split attention <https://www.cnbc.com/2023/05/23/elon-musk-splits-time-across-spacex-tesla-and-twitter-heres-how.html> with X <https://fortune.com/company/twitter/>; off-color remarks <https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/22/world/europe/elon-musk-auschwitz-jewish-antisemitism.html>, the worst of which have been bigoted <https://www.cbsnews.com/news/elon-musk-actual-truth-antisemitic-post-backlash-advertisers/>; and the lack <https://www.reuters.com/business/autos-transportation/tesla-gross-margin-falls-fourth-quarter-2024-01-24/> of clear guidance about when new models would be released—so long as the stock kept up its stellar performance. But since the start of the year Tesla’s stock has fallen 43%. Tesla also had its first quarterly sales decline in four years. All this comes as the global EV market seems to be flatlining rather than growing, as many carmakers predicted. All that has some of Tesla’s

metadata.title: Tesla will try to stem the bleeding on its earnings call after its worst sales quarter in four years, a round of price cuts, and a sinking share price

49822c87-eec3-4a4c-833f-2befd3be671c.text: Viecha’s exit came soon after senior vice president Drew Baglino resigned and cashed out a $181 million stake in the company <https://fortune.com/2024/04/26/tesla-elon-musk-drew-baglino-insider-sale-ron-baron/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>. Baglino had been with Tesla for 18 years and was a stalwart among investors and analysts. Rohan Patel, the company’s vice president of public policy and business development, parted ways at the same time as Baglino <https://fortune.com/2024/04/15/tesla-top-engineering-exec-drew-baglino-elon-musk-ceo-succession/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>.

metadata.title: Amid Tesla’s bloodletting, top exec sends Musk a message: The company has ‘taken its pound of flesh’

49e371f3-f3b7-42ca-af60-5f1bbd52a319.text:
But in recent months, after recalling millions of its cars <https://qz.com/tesla-car-recalls-china-model-y-accidents-autopilot-1851144035> and watching vehicle sales start to decline, the company has been hit by layoffs, hiring freezes, and senior resignations.

“With [Tesla’s] rapid growth there has been duplication of roles and job functions in certain areas,” Musk wrote to employees last month <https://qz.com/tesla-ceo-elon-musk-tweets-ev-q1-sales-1851385048>, as he explained that at least 14,000 workers were set to lose their jobs. “There is nothing I hate more, but it must be done.”

Since then, employees have gotten layoff notices in waves over the course of four weeks. "I keep waiting for Elon to send another email and tell us they're finally done firing people," one current Tesla worker told Business Insider. <https://www.businessinsider.com/more-tesla-layoffs-workers-post-2024-5>

metadata.title: Tesla quietly slashed over 3,400 job postings, leaving just 3 listed in the U.S.—but applicants may face confined spaces, hazardous materials, and 12-hour days

7bebe3db-e8f6-4ade-9f3c-0d60c060bcfe.text: Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment. \n\nMusk’s pay was rescinded in January by a Delaware Chancery Court judge who determined the board’s process for awarding stock options then valued at $56 billion to Musk lacked independence and that the deal wasn’t properly negotiated. After the ruling, Musk announced that he would seek to move Tesla’s headquarters from Delaware to Texas, where courts might be more deferential. The Tesla board has asked investors to reapprove Musk’s pay and the move south. Shareholder advisory firms Glass Lewis <https://fortune.com/2024/05/30/tesla-claps-back-adviser-critical-musk-billions/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks> and Institutional Shareholder Services have recommended that investors vote against the pay package, while the Tesla board and its independent chair Robyn Denholm are urging investors <https://fortune.com/2024/05/18/tesla-chair-robyn-denholm-ceo-elon-musk-pay-package-oversight-annual-meeting/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks> to back the company and its CEO.

He and other investors in the past have complained that Musk isn’t focused enough on Tesla and is distracted by social media and a half-dozen other companies where he holds leadership roles, including X <https://fortune.com/company/twitter/>, xAI, Neuralink, and the Boring Company.

"The year-to-date gap between box office performance this year and last is getting moderately slimmer. It's now down 16.1% from 2023 thanks to a run of recent successes. But performance still pales in comparison to pre-pandemic standards. On July 14 in 2019, the annual box office take was at $6.2 billion. This year it’s at $4.1 billion so far.

“A very unpredictable summer movie season continues,” said Paul Dergarabedian, the senior media analyst for Comscore. “And after a slow start in May (it) has continued to surprise and impress with expected as well as unexpected hits adding bottom-line dollars to the industry’s most important season.”", mimetype='text/plain', start_char_idx=None, end_char_idx=None, text_template='{metadata_str}

In limited release, A24 opened “Sing Sing <https://apnews.com/article/sing-movie-review-34e3e640aa9df9ae4f1aeffe6e93ecb6>,” an early Oscar contender, in four theaters in New York and Los Angeles. With sellouts in both locations, it made $137,119, one of the best limited openings of the year. The film from director Greg Kwedar is about an arts program at the prison and features many real life participants, including Clarence Maclin in his film debut. “Sing Sing” will continue playing on four screens through July and expand nationwide in August.

Finally, “Twisters,” which opens in North America on Thursday, began its international rollout this weekend, earning $11.5 million from 38 markets including in Australia, Mexico and Brazil.

In its wake comes “Deadpool & Wolverine,” the first Marvel release of the summer <https://fortune.com/asia/2024/06/17/marvel-deadpool-movie-china-release-disney-box-office-earnings/>.

e1c45212-d1e4-455a-b60b-126afb234af9.text: The cumulative summer box office clocked in at over $3.6 billion domestically <https://fortune.com/2024/08/18/disney-films-42-percent-summer-box-office-aliens-deadpool-wolverine/> – a dip of 10% from 2023’s $4 billion season that could likely be attributed to the “Barbenheimer” <https://apnews.com/article/barbie-oppenheimer-barbenheimer-box-office-3ff25c0a3acf7b568866c2ff307d0108> box office craze that drew crowds en masse to see “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” last summer.\n\nThe close of the season brought what Dergarabedian described as a “stranglehold” of familiar summer hits on box office rankings, with “Alien: Romulus” and “It Ends With Us” rounding out the top three for the second weekend in a row. Six of the top 10 films of the weekend had been playing for three or more weeks.

f239a35c-18ea-4c02-8650-6221c5b24529.text:
The third installment in an R-rated, f-bomb-laden trilogy is the first since Disney acquired rights to make movies based on the Marvel comic-book character, after closing the $71.3 billion acquisition of 21st Century Fox in 2019. Chinese regulators barred the first Deadpool from the country when it was released in 2016, and they allowed only a PG-13-rated version of 2018’s Deadpool 2.

The first two Deadpool movies grossed a combined $1.5 billion at the global box office. Deadpool & Wolverine is scheduled to be released in the US in July.

Another franchise Disney acquired as part of the Fox deal was Avatar. The second film, released in 2022, was also cleared by Chinese regulators and became the third-highest-grossing movie in history, with $2.3 billion in ticket sales. 

On June 14, Disney released Inside Out 2, generating a $295 million global haul in ticket sales that scored the biggest opening weekend in history for an animated film.

2f512b70-0570-4612-a809-61fceca4ce67.text: Meanwhile, “Deadpool & Wolverine,” which co-stars Hugh Jackman, continued its march through box-office records. The film, directed by Shawn Levy, is only the second R-rated movie to reach $1 billion, following 2019’s “Joker.” <https://apnews.com/article/us-news-ap-top-news-movies-fall-films-entertainment-f2eb430a7c5b4b4eb366c82547738cfd> In three weeks, it’s already one of the most lucrative Marvel releases and trails only Disney’s other 2024 smash, “Inside Out” ($1.6 billion worldwide) among movies released this year.\n\nLively makes a cameo in “Deadpool & Wolverine” but she both stars in and produced “It Ends With Us.” Adapted from the bestselling romance novel by Colleen Hoover, Lively stars as Lily Bloom, a Boston florist torn between two men, one from her present life (Justin Baldoni, who also directed the film) and another who was her first love (Brandon Sklenar).

“Inside Out 2” landed in fourth place with $8.3 million. The Disney and Pixar release this week became the biggest animated release ever with $613.4 million domestically (surpassing “Incredibles 2”) and $1.5 billion globally. It also passed “Top Gun: Maverick” to become the 12th highest-earning global release of all time.

It all adds up to one of the top 10 domestic grossing weekends of all time, with $277.5 million, according to Comscore. That puts it ahead of this weekend last year, when “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” helped propel the box office to over $216.9 million in their second weekends.

“This is one for the history books," Dergarabedian said. ”Hopefully this will carry over into August."

661b6ef5-01ed-4a25-ad9e-851e7d5a9ac9.txt.LLM_answer: According to the sources provided, there is no specific mention of a major natural disaster that occurred in 2023, causing significant global impact. However, it is mentioned that the country has averaged around eight major weather events per year that caused at least $1 billion in damage since the 1980s [2]. Additionally, it is stated that the severity and frequency of major weather events are likely to increase [2].
661b6ef5-01ed-4a25-ad9e-851e7d5a9ac9.txt.LLM_query: Was it a hurricane, earthquake, or wildfire?

fbe69cd3-f5a3-4c72-bdd3-6918797a4ded.text: The tornados <https://www.npr.org/2023/03/25/1166045610/tornado-alabama-mississippi> that recently tore through Sharkey County, Mississippi, left a trail of horrific damage. More than 20 people were killed–an unusually high toll for a single event. Natural disasters cause substantial property and economic damage <https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/access/billions/> to the U.S. every year, but because of better building quality, they have far fewer fatalities than similar events in developing countries <https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/02/08/world/turkey-syria-earthquake>.\n\nAccording to a 2021 Federal Reserve survey <https://www.federalreserve.gov/publications/2022-economic-well-being-of-us-households-in-2021-executive-summary.htm>, 16% of Americans experienced some disruption in the previous year from natural disasters, with property damage being the most commonly reported occurrence.

metadata.title: How to protect your home—and your wallet—against natural disasters

1da201da-0017-4f8c-a9c9-75cfce89cab9.text: There are about two more months of hurricane season, and multiple hurricanes have already made landfall. Since the 1980s, the country has averaged around eight major weather events per year that caused at least $1 billion in damage. In the past five years the average number of major weather events causing at least a billion dollars in damage has climbed, reaching 18 as of last October. At the time, John Rogers, chief innovation officer at CoreLogic, told me <https://fortune.com/2023/10/28/extreme-weather-23-billion-problem-housing-market-flooding-insurance-premiums-resilience/> it was only going to get worse. “The severity and frequency of major weather events, unfortunately, is likely to go up,” Rogers said.

f23cc9d7-a1a3-4dec-a43c-686b8133b30a.text: It’s given rise to uninsurable properties <https://fortune.com/2024/09/24/uninsurable-homes-selling-all-cash-discount/>. An estimated $1.6 trillion in property value of uninsured homes was at risk three years ago and 6.1 million homeowners were uninsured, a report published this year found. The situation has likely worsened as insurance woes are becoming more prominent. Just think, you can now look up homes in Zillow <https://fortune.com/company/zillow-group/>, and it will present you with climate risks <https://fortune.com/2024/09/27/home-listings-climate-risks-zillow-floods-wildfire-extreme-heat-wind/>.\n\nThis story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/2024/10/08/hurricane-milton-billion-of-dollars-losses-insurers/>

f486b025-2fbc-4efd-bca8-ecc95977d8b8.text:
The disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active <https://apnews.com/article/hurricanes-busy-season-warm-water-la-nina-0fe7c4cb0367e8b56ac63ff663839df0> in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.

The disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.

In Hallandale Beach, Alex Demchemko, was walking his Russian spaniel Lex along the still-flooded sidewalks near the Airbnb <https://fortune.com/company/airbnb/> where he’s lived after arriving from Russia last month to seek asylum in the U.S.

“We didn’t come out from our apartment, but we had to walk with our dog,” Demchemko said. “A lot of flashes, raining, a lot of floating cars and a lot of left cars without drivers, and there was a lot of water on the streets. It was kind of catastrophic.”

metadata.title: Florida flash floods overwhelm airports and fill streets with abandoned cars: ‘Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie’

6ee4dd63-9034-4af7-bd71-146b19fb90c1.text: Hurricane Debby, which pummeled Florida and the Carolinas last month before moving up the East Coast <https://fortune.com/2024/08/12/hurricane-debby-remnants-thousands-businesses-homes-without-power-northeast/>, caused an estimated $1.4 billion of property losses in the U.S <https://www.insurancejournal.com/news/southeast/2024/08/15/788522.htm>. and over $2 billion in Canada <https://www.reinsurancene.ws/hurricane-debby-caused-2-5bn-in-insured-damage-in-quebec-catiq/>, according to estimates. (It was the costliest event in the history of Quebec, Reinsurance News noted <https://www.reinsurancene.ws/hurricane-debby-caused-2-5bn-in-insured-damage-in-quebec-catiq/>.) But an analysis by First Street found <https://firststreet.org/research-library/first-street-recreation-of-hurricane-debby-finds-majority-of-damaged-homes-outside-of-fema-flood-zones> that nearly 8 in 10 of\nthat nearly 8 in 10 of the damage was outside of historical FEMA flood zones, meaning the affected properties were unlikely to have flood insurance, and their owners less able to weather a catastrophic financial loss.

metadata.title: The next banking crisis could come from climate change

1bb45ec1-037d-47f1-be96-edabc9d4a472.text: Much of the damage is because of flooding. Studies show that hurricanes are getting wetter <https://apnews.com/article/us-news-ap-top-news-sc-state-wire-typhoon-mangkhut-nc-state-wire-47d8e0bf05354260931de08ad9976a37#:~:text=WASHINGTON%20(AP)%20%E2%80%94%20A%20warmer,and%20thus%20dumping%20more%20rain.> because of the buildup of heat-trapping gases from the burning of coal, oil and gas. Basic physics dictates that clouds hold 4% more moisture for every degree Fahrenheit (7% for every degree Celsius), and that falls as rain.\n\n“There is scientific agreement that floods and flooding from these hurricanes is becoming more frequent and more severe. So it is likely that we’re going to be seeing a higher frequency of storms like Helene in the future,” said Karen Clark, who founded her namesake firm. “It’s not really an insurance issue because it’s not privately insured. This is really a societal issue and political question. How do we want to deal with this?”

"Fugate continued to use his color-coded map when he joined FEMA under President Barack Obama <https://apnews.com/hub/barack-obama>. He was the agency's administrator in 2011 when a deadly tornado tore through the town of Joplin, Missouri. Both of the town's Waffle Houses reportedly stayed open.

The restaurant chain's disaster readiness is no coincidence. Seven locations were destroyed and 100 more shut down in 2005 during Hurricane Katrina <https://apnews.com/today-in-history/august-29>, but company executives saw business skyrocket at restaurants that reopened quickly.

They soon embraced a business strategy <https://www.wafflehouse.com/how-to-measure-a-storms-fury-one-breakfast-at-a-time/> centered around keeping their restaurants operable during and after a disaster, according to the company's website. The chain said it has invested in portable generators

3d82d8e7-6e5a-4a3c-88fa-d91e25bd4511.text:
Lana Vierra misses the swing set at her Lahaina home, which was reduced to ashes in the wildfires <https://fortune.com/2024/04/22/hawaii-target-maui-vacation-rentals-lahaina-wildfire-housing-shortage-exorbitant-prices/> that swept through her community last summer.

“Multiple generations went through there playing in my front yard," she said. "Just with the animals and the turtles and the deer and goats that we once had in that little tiny yard.”
A grandmother of four and a mother of five, Vierra had lived in the home on a corner lot since 1991. She and ten family members, including a baby less than one year old, were displaced in the deadliest U.S. wildfire <https://apnews.com/article/hawaii-wildfires-recovery-maui-lahaina-identifications-4e444bc0217bc1e0779f87e641a1b235> in more than a century. In the weeks that followed, she and her adult children applied for and received many different kinds of assistance, including from the People's Fund of Maui, an initiative set up by Oprah Winfrey and Dwayne Johnson <https://apnews.com/article/maui-wildfires-oprah-dwayne-johnson-donations-0e59c2e1dc06b8519c9b453c978ed1b9>.

metadata.title: Oprah Winfrey and Dwayne Johnson donate more than $10m they pledged for Maui wildfire survivors as 8,100 people get checks from People’s Fund

e8869019-0bc4-4a9c-a04c-bb1bd7b0d222.text:
Western North Carolina and the Asheville area were hit especially hard <https://apnews.com/article/climate-change-hurricane-helene-flooding-north-carolina-f49b2a6bf2b549473e0211f883332592>, with flooding that wiped out buildings, roads, utilities and land in a way that nobody expected, let alone prepared for. Inland areas in parts of Georgia and Tennessee were also washed out.

The Oak Forest neighborhood in south Asheville lives up to its name, with trees towering over 1960s era ranch-style houses on large lots. But on Sept. 27, as Helene’s remnants swept through western north Carolina, many of those trees came crashing down, sometimes landing on houses.

Julianne Johnson said she was coming upstairs from the basement to help her 5-year-old son pick out clothes that day when her husband began to yell that a giant oak was falling diagonally across the yard. The tree mostly missed the house, but still crumpled part of a metal porch and damaged the roof. Then, Johnson said, her basement flooded.

ad1bd84f-ff9f-4bd5-b807-b56924ad46d5.text: That unnamed storm system <https://apnews.com/article/rain-florida-flooding-what-to-know-6f0a512f1406cee0e37a31df1c75d3cf> coincided with the early start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active <https://apnews.com/article/hurricanes-busy-season-warm-water-la-nina-0fe7c4cb0367e8b56ac63ff663839df0> in recent memory.\n\nThis story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/2024/06/17/from-record-heat-arizona-snow-rockies-unseasonable-extreme-weather-us/>

b8666aa4-d44a-40b8-b3a0-68d1a22e3101.text:
In the case of Jamaica, the country has a large disaster safety net to fall back on, totaling $1.6 billion. That makes it one of the most prepared Caribbean nations when it comes to dealing with the financial cost of hurricanes, and means it hasn’t been left in the lurch because its cat bond didn’t pay out.

Beryl also didn’t trigger cat bonds for named storms in Mexico or Texas. And cat bond losses were contained in 2023, partly because the US didn’t suffer a single, large hurricane event.

It remains to be seen how the current season will play out. While Beryl was raging, researchers at Colorado State University updated their 2024 forecast <https://tropical.colostate.edu/forecasting.html> and now see “a well-above-average probability” that major hurricanes will make landfall in the US and Caribbean. That adds to the risk that property may be damaged and cat bonds will end up getting triggered.

e19d5fa4-1472-49ec-965e-cdb86f8148eb.txt.LLM_question: Why is sleep important for overall health?
e19d5fa4-1472-49ec-965e-cdb86f8148eb.txt.LLM_answer: Sleep is essential for overall health because it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support healthy brain function and physical health [2]. For instance, sleep helps to regulate the heart and circulatory system, metabolism, and immune system, which can reduce the risk of chronic health conditions like heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [1]. Additionally, sleep aids in learning and forming long-term memories, and those who don't get enough high-quality sleep might have problems focusing and thinking clearly [2].
e19d5fa4-1472-49ec-965e-cdb86f8148eb.txt.LLM_query: What are the specific health benefits of getting adequate sleep?

261d70dc-c826-4af8-83c7-1f2fc69c3a84.text: Proper rest offers myriad short- and long-term benefits <https://fortune.com/well/article/bed-9-p-m-every-night-health-benefits/> for both your physical and mental health, from reducing stress <https://fortune.com/well/article/cortisol-how-to-lower-stress-hormone/> and improving memory to lowering risk of heart disease and stroke <https://fortune.com/well/article/anger-heart-disease-attack-stroke-blood-vessel-function/>, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) <https://www.cdc.gov/sleep/about/index.html>. Getting sufficient sleep may even save others’ lives, the agency points out, as rested drivers <https://fortune.com/2018/02/08/drowsy-driving-cause-crashes/> are less likely to cause motor vehicle crashes resulting in injury and death.

metadata.title: Can’t get a good night’s rest? Watch out for these 8 ways you may be sabotaging your sleep

f3b19072-0048-4b02-a31b-d0902f204c5e.text: As a child, you likely had a bedtime routine <https://fortune.com/well/article/headspace-app-finding-your-best-sleep/>: take a bath, put on your pajamas, brush your teeth, and get tucked in with your favorite book. Just maybe, on the weekends you got to stay up <https://fortune.com/well/2023/09/11/night-owls-unhealthy-lifestyle-habits-higher-risk-diabetes/> an extra half hour <https://fortune.com/well/article/sleeping-in-weekends-heart-disease-risk/>. Remember not worrying about an alarm clock, when getting enough sleep was your parents’ responsibility? Those were the days.\n\nWhile adulthood comes with the freedom to go to bed whenever you please <https://fortune.com/well/2023/05/13/best-time-to-sleep/>, the absence of a regimen that primes your body for adequate rest is among the plethora of poor habits that may be damaging your sleep health <https://fortune.com/well/2023/05/03/how-to-recover-from-a-bad-night-sleep/>.

metadata.title: Can’t get a good night’s rest? Watch out for these 8 ways you may be sabotaging your sleep

5e2648cc-02b0-4444-b690-2efdac8b7f05.text:
Why does getting enough sleep matter?

How you feel when you’re awake partially depends on what happens when you’re sleeping, according to the CDC <https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/sleep/why-sleep-important>. When you sleep, your body performs work that supports healthy brain function and physical health. And for children and teens, getting enough sleep aids healthy growth and development.

Adequate sleep supports the following body functions, the CDC says:

 * Heart and circulatory system: People who don’t sleep enough or wake up often may have a higher risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and/or stroke.

 * Metabolism: Not getting enough quality shut eye may lead to insulin resistance, increased eating (especially of unhealthy foods), and decreased physical activity, all of which contribute to obesity, which carries its own health risks.

 * Immune systems: A particular type of immune cell works harder when you sleep. That’s why those who don’t get enough sleep may get sick more often.

metadata.title: Waking up before your alarm? Falling back to sleep can make you more exhausted—here’s the cut off time when you should just stay awake

33583613-b779-4178-9054-0b780f953104.text:
* Cognition: Sleep aids in learning and forming long-term memories. Those who don’t get enough high-quality sleep might have problems focusing and thinking clearly. 
Copious medical studies support the need for adequate sleep, and quality sleep. Cases in point:

 * People who get less than five hours of sleep each night are more than three times more likely to have a stroke than those who get the recommended seven hours, according to a study published in April in the journal Neurology <https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/05/bad-sleep-increased-stroke-risk-tips-better-sleep-apnea-snoring-snorting/>.

 * People who struggle to fall asleep and stay asleep may also be at a greater risk of a stroke, according to research published in June in the journal Neurology <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/07/insomnia-symptoms-trouble-sleeping-increased-stroke-risk/>.

metadata.title: Waking up before your alarm? Falling back to sleep can make you more exhausted—here’s the cut off time when you should just stay awake

151308c4-2286-4d7f-88ca-1bc6b7824ea4.text:
Sleep 101

Doctors and scientists have long been touting the benefits of sleep for the brain and body. It’s true—sleep is an essential part of maintaining overall well-being. When you are well rested, your mood improves, your stress levels decrease, and you tend to feel more productive. 

Beyond <https://fortune.com/company/overstock-com/> quantity of sleep, research has shown that the quality <https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/sleep-diet-exercise-goals/> of your sleep matters too. While current guidelines recommend adults get between seven and nine hours <https://www.cdc.gov/sleep/about_sleep/how_much_sleep.html> of sleep, over a third of Americans do not meet the minimum. It’s too easy to give in to the over-stimulating activities at your fingertips—hello, TikTok—instead of turning the lights off. Minutes scrolling on social media before bed turn into hours, and screens have made it harder to shut off the brain and prepare for a good night’s rest—ever heard of revenge bedtime procrastination <https://fortune.com/well/2022/08/25/how-to-stop-revenge-bedtime-procrastination/>?

metadata.title: Your ultimate guide to getting a good night’s sleep

e36156e3-5ee6-4fb3-9e27-6ae195a24ca4.text:
Getting little sleep is associated with an increased risk of chronic health conditions like heart disease and stroke. Sleeping less puts people at risk of mental health problems like anxiety and depression. One study found older adults who get five or fewer hours <https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/19/sleeping-five-hours-or-less-can-raise-your-risk-for-multiple-conditions-including-cancer-and-diabetes/> of sleep are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions. So, improving sleep can, in turn, improve our lives. Even following certain sleep habits <https://fortune.com/well/2023/02/23/healthy-sleep-habits-for-aging/> can increase your life expectancy, per one study. 

Sleep basics

How much sleep do I need? 

According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), adults need at least seven hours of sleep. For those 65 and older, the CDC recommends between seven and eight hours of sleep each night. 

Why is it harder to sleep for older adults?

metadata.title: Your ultimate guide to getting a good night’s sleep

4c3af322-0daa-4140-9adf-536c37bb5a30.text: “Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep their benefits are greatly reduced,” Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director, Indiana Sleep Center, expert at SleepFoundation.org <https://www.sleepfoundation.org/>, and coauthor of Sleep to Heal: 7 Simple Steps to Better Sleep <https://www.amazon.com/Sleep-Heal-Refresh-Restore-Revitalize/dp/1630062340/ref=sr_1_1?crid=222HN5DUONGAM&keywords=sleep+to+heal&qid=1677545988&sprefix=sleep+to+heal%2Caps%2C123&sr=8-1>, previously told Fortune. “Sleep is important for metabolic health, immune health, muscle repair, optimal brain function, and mental health. Optimal sleep not only adds years to your life, but life to your years.”\n\nThis story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/well/2023/07/30/how-to-fall-back-asleep/>

metadata.title: This is why you randomly wake up at 4 a.m. (and how to fall back asleep fast)

e73a5bbc-3c23-4b3d-a716-491554f863bf.text: “Everyone has a different kind of job with different kinds of demands, and a lack of sleep can present many challenges for us, as far as emotion regulation [and] our ability to focus,” Snowden says. “These are big capacities that we need to get through the day, to be productive and do our jobs well, and to be present for our loved ones.”\n\nMore than a third of American adults do not get the recommended minimum of seven hours of sleep a night as it is, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) <https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/p0215-enough-sleep.html>. Prioritizing sleep means investing in a quality mattress <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-mattress/> having good sleep hygiene <https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/19/sleeping-five-hours-or-less-can-raise-your-risk-for-multiple-conditions-including-cancer-and-diabetes/>, including waking up around the same time each day, limiting screens before bed, not consuming alcohol or caffeine in the evenings, and having a wind-down routine.

metadata.title: Waking up at 5 a.m. every day could improve your life. 5 key steps can help make it work for you

8835c876-8c2c-4eb0-af86-ee0384855939.text:
Key takeaways

 * Seven to nine hours of sleep per night can help with health and fitness goals 
 * Quality of sleep determined by six factors: regularity, satisfaction, alertness, timing, efficiency and duration 
 * Sleep is closely tied to cardiovascular health 
Better sleep may be the solution for everything from adding years to your life <https://fortune.com/well/2023/02/23/healthy-sleep-habits-for-aging/> to better health and wellness. According to research presented at the American Heart Association’s Epidemiology, Prevention, Lifestyle & Cardiometabolic Health Scientific Sessions 2023 <https://professional.heart.org/en/meetings/epi-lifestyle> in Boston earlier this week, people who reported regular, uninterrupted sleep were better at sticking to exercise and diet plans while trying to lose weight.

metadata.title: Researchers share the one thing that may be sabotaging your health and fitness goals

1ffcacf2-d8b8-4b33-a7fd-73797e2b4240.text: Proper sleep hygiene <https://fortune.com/well/article/headspace-app-finding-your-best-sleep/>, the CDC counsels, requires a consistent sleep schedule in which you go to bed and wake up at the same times daily—including weekends. The American Academy of Sleep Medicine <https://sleepeducation.org/healthy-sleep/healthy-sleep-habits/> takes it a step further, advocating for sleep regularity even when you’re on vacation. Such a routine keeps your circadian rhythm, or body clock, in check. Out-of-sync rhythms have been shown to increase risk of developing immune, neurologic, psychiatric, and cardiometabolic disorders <https://www.jci.org/articles/view/148286>. A study published earlier this year in the journal Sleep <https://academic.oup.com/sleep/article/47/1/zsad253/7280269?login=false> found that people with irregular sleep patterns have a higher risk of premature death.

metadata.title: Sleeping in on weekends could cut your risk of heart disease by up to 20%, new study shows

034eb379-24ba-433c-a137-04bfb2aeb174.text: Adults need between seven and nine hours of sleep at night to feel well-rested, so moving up your bedtime by just 15 minutes and eventually 30 may be beneficial and help you get there. It’s essential because the quality of sleep depends on aligning your bedtime and wake time with the body’s natural clock, and the deepest sleep may happen between 10 p.m. and 2 a.m <https://fortune.com/well/article/bed-9-p-m-every-night-health-benefits/>. Sleep experts have previously told Fortune <https://fortune.com/well/article/bed-9-p-m-every-night-health-benefits/> that the best sleep habits stick when done in small increments over time <https://fortune.com/well/2024/02/14/atomic-habits-james-clear-app-goals-atoms/>. Dr. Raj Dasgupta, an internal medicine doctor and sleep scientist, has also touted a 30- to 60-minute wind-down routine before bed to calm the nervous system and set yourself up for success.\n\nWhether you choose one or all of these adjustments, prioritize what makes you feel better and integrate it into your day more routinely.

metadata.title: 8 micro changes to help yourself feel better today

6a9b5214-277b-4ef0-b6f0-0d643aebd986.text:
2. Get enough sleep and exercise

Both Bennett and Azzaro underscore the importance of consistent good sleep <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/> and exercise <https://fortune.com/well/2023/08/12/how-much-exercise-do-i-need-each-week-does-walking-count/>.

Studies <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6984036/> have shown that poor sleep quality can lead to higher stress levels, making it more difficult to handle daily stressors and regulate emotions.
Aim for seven to eight hours a night, says Bennett. Sleep habits <https://fortune.com/well/article/should-you-go-back-to-sleep-if-you-wake-up-before-your-alarm/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks> are also important. These include going to bed and waking at the same time each day; sleeping in a quiet, dark, cool room <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/02/best-temperature-for-sleep/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>; removing devices from the bedroom and taking a break from them before bedtime; and avoiding caffeine and alcohol before bed, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.

0a572e77-ac90-448a-9c3d-f885ff77089b.txt.LLM_question: What is the name of the online retail company founded by Jeff Bezos?
0a572e77-ac90-448a-9c3d-f885ff77089b.txt.LLM_answer: The online retail company founded by Jeff Bezos is Amazon [7]. Interestingly, when Amazon was first founded 30 years ago, its name wasn't even Amazon; it was Cadabra—short for abracadabra [7]. Over time, the company evolved and became the Amazon we know today, with a massive advertising business generating nearly $47 billion in revenue in 2023 [2].

metadata.title: Amazon Prime Day is a big shopping event for scammers too, experts warn

56e1eac1-23bd-461e-87e9-8ec3100d6fd2.text:
Amid increasing pressure to tackle counterfeit products, Amazon has reported getting rid of millions of phony products in recent years. The company said it also blocked billions of bad listings from making it on to its site. In 2023, Amazon the company said more than 7 million counterfeit items were "identified, seized and appropriately disposed of.” The online retailer has also filed multiple lawsuits against fake review brokers <https://apnews.com/article/technology-lawsuits-amazoncom-inc-03329beafb3b1eba170a13c99ee0d318>.

Amazon notes customers can also report fake reviews and other scams on its website <https://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html?nodeId=GRGRY7AQ3LMPXVCV>. If a shopper purchases a counterfeit item detected by the company, Amazon has said it will “proactively contact” the customer and provide a refund.

This story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/2024/07/16/amazon-prime-day-big-shopping-event-scammers-experts-warn/>

metadata.title: Amazon Prime Day is a big shopping event for scammers too, experts warn

2d25143d-e4a6-441a-b395-59fad0fa6634.text:
Consumers might need to be more vigilant this year than ever before. In June, the Better Business Bureau published a report that said it received a record number of phishing reports in 2023. Reports are also trending up so far this year, the organization said.

Meanwhile, in a report released this month, the Israel-founded cybersecurity company Check Point Software Technologies said more than 1,230 new websites that associated themselves with Amazon popped up in June. The vast majority of them were malicious or appeared suspicious, according to Check Point.

Scott Knapp, director of worldwide buyer risk prevention at Amazon, identifies two areas that the company has seen hoaxes around come Prime Day in recent years: Prime membership <https://apnews.com/article/amazon-prime-ftc-lawsuit-9e60955fc71d9891ed16c5b856222279> and order confirmations.

metadata.title: Amazon Prime Day is a big shopping event for scammers too, experts warn

1b1f9df1-baaa-463c-87fc-dd1198bbd659.text: As that has happened, Amazon has built a massive advertising business <https://fortune.com/2024/05/09/amazon-andy-jassy-earnings-accelerated-growth-aws-ads> within its own shopping empire, generating nearly $47 billion in revenue in 2023. Google’s core business, of course, is also advertising <https://fortune.com/2024/04/26/youtube-was-hero-google-alphabet-q1-earnings-netflix-competition/>. A product search that begins on Amazon (or Walmart or Temu or Shein, for that matter) is a product search that Google can’t monetize with ads. Part of the problem if you’re Google, or the advantage if you’re Amazon, is that many Amazon customers who become reliant on the Prime shipping <https://fortune.com/2024/04/24/amazon-unlimited-grocery-delivery-prime/> program don’t price-compare or shop around except, perhaps, on expensive items.

metadata.title: Amazon Prime Day is July 16-17: Here’s how Google plans to capitalize on the hype, according to a Google Shopping exec

ba0a8b60-ad86-4f4e-9a7c-68dd984820be.text: Maybe more should. To be clear, Amazon has a reputation for low prices. Last year, for example, e-commerce analytics firm Profitero named Amazon the online retailer with the lowest prices for the seventh year in a row. (Note that a company like Temu wouldn’t be included in a research study like that one because it doesn’t sell brand-name goods across a wide selection of categories.)\n\nBut price-comparison research can indeed be worthwhile. I recently was in the market for an exciting purchase: an air filter for a furnace. For a variety of uninteresting reasons, I wanted to buy a single filter and not a multipack as I usually would. After wading through multipacks on Amazon’s search results page, I found a single filter for sale. It cost around $18.

679979b4-42a2-4011-be58-66eabd749b10.text: To be clear, the company is facing myriad challenges, including some self-induced. Its plans to reinvent brick-and-mortar shopping through technology <https://fortune.com/2024/04/17/amazon-just-walk-out-co-inventor-dilip-kumar-explains-changes-to-cashierless-tech-strategy/> haven’t gone as planned. The Federal Trade Commission’s antitrust lawsuit against Amazon, however unlikely, could someday force the company to overhaul its business or even split it into parts. Amazon’s relationship with the hundreds of thousands of sellers who account for 60% of the company’s product sales has probably never been worse no matter what Amazon’s CEO says <https://fortune.com/2024/04/11/andy-jassy-shareholder-letter-amazon-seller-relationship/>. And as the nascent generative AI sector has boomed, Amazon has found itself in some instances trailing competitors. \n\nBut for today, considering the financial results Amazon is showing, and considering the fact that the company is finally at a size that it can, as Jassy said on the earnings call, both invest aggressively in its future while also pumping out real profits, this certainly feels like the Amazon everyone should have feared.

metadata.title: This is the Amazon everyone should have feared

a9c76b27-7270-4b71-8a5e-4b12d7e2e4ee.text: Then there\'s Amazon\'s "third-party seller services" division—another highly profitable business line consisting of all the fees, however controversial <https://fortune.com/2024/03/08/ftc-amazon-seller-fees-inbound-placement-low-inventory-antitrust/>, that the company charges independent merchants to sell and ship goods sold through its shopping sites. That business grew 16% year over year in the first quarter, and the $35 billion in revenue it generated is almost as much as AWS and Amazon\'s ad business combined.\n\nOver the decade-plus that I’ve covered this company, it’s become common for stock analysts to ask Amazon officials on earnings calls whether the company is currently operating in more of an investing cycle than a profits one, or vice versa. And on last week’s earnings call, an analyst posed such a question once again. But the answer was much different than ever before.

metadata.title: This is the Amazon everyone should have feared

7b7b25a0-fad9-42cf-aee6-6ec2213b2bdf.text: Amazon (no. 2 <https://fortune.com/company/amazon-com/> in the Fortune 500) under CEO Andy Jassy has finally hit an inflection point <https://fortune.com/2024/05/09/amazon-andy-jassy-earnings-accelerated-growth-aws-ads/> where it can both invest heavily in long-term bets like generative AI <https://fortune.com/2024/04/30/amazon-aws-100-billion-revenue-gen-ai-earnings/> while at the same time produce significant profits, Fortune’s Jason Del Rey recently reported. In April, Amazon reported Q1 2024 earnings <https://ir.aboutamazon.com/news-release/news-release-details/2024/Amazon.com-Announces-First-Quarter-Results-68b9258cd/default.aspx> with revenue of $143.3 billion, up 13% year over year and $10 billion in profit. \n\nAmazon Web Services (AWS) revenue in Q1 was $25 billion, an increase of 17% year over year. AWS is now a $100 billion annualized revenue run rate business, Olsavsky said on the April earnings call.

metadata.title: Amazon’s market cap hits $2 trillion as its CFO keeps an eye on AI—and cutting costs

7feec9b6-4fa0-4169-bec0-9f43ff4486ee.text:
"Happy Friday. This is Fortune tech correspondent Jason Del Rey.

At Amazon's founding 30 years ago today, its name wasn’t even Amazon. It was Cadabra—short for abracadabra. 

As in magic. 

For the last three decades, when Amazon operates at its best, magic is just what it can feel like for customers. Endless aisles of merchandise available with a click of a button from just about anywhere. Magic. An item showing up at your door mere hours after pressing “Buy Now.” Magic. The ability to grab a juice off the shelf at a corner store and legally walk out without stopping to pay, or maybe you do stop to pay—but with your freaking palm. Magic.

At one time or another, you could say something similar about an experience across Amazon’s other business lines too, whether it be Kindle, Amazon Web Services, or maybe even Prime Video. Someday, that might be the feeling people also get when they use Amazon’s healthcare service or Kuiper satellite broadband offering or an invention that isn’t even in the works yet, like an Amazon commercial airline or something far afield that only the AI gods could predict.", mimetype='text/plain', start_char_idx=None, end_char_idx=None, text_template='{metadata_str}

c26952c4-1a78-437d-bd99-b3a02c1ef721.text: Kurzweil, 59, declared his career as an inventor at age 5. He grew up in Queens, New York, one of two children (he has a younger sister named Enid) of Fredric and Hannah Kurzweil, Viennese Jews who fled the Nazis in 1938. His parents encouraged their son\'s ambition. "Ideas were the religion of our household," he says. "They saw science and technology as the way of the future and a way to make money and not struggle the way they did." Fredric, a composer and conductor, died of heart disease at 58, an event that would have a lasting impact on his son. Kurzweil discovered computers at age 12, and quickly demonstrated an amazing facility with technology. At 14 he wangled a job as the computer programmer at the research department of Head Start, the federal government\'s early-childhood-development program. While there he wrote software that was later distributed by IBM <https://fortune.com/company/ibm/> (IBM) with its mainframes. At 17 he won an international science contest by building a computer that analyzed the works of Chopin and Beethoven to compose music; that trick landed him on the TV show

metadata.title: The smartest (or the nuttiest) futurist on earth

99dc3c2d-3483-4f81-b350-7c566a369e8a.text: These days Kurzweil organizes his business interests—including FatKat and Ray & Terry\'s Longevity Products, which sells supplements—under the umbrella of Kurzweil Technologies. The company takes up all of one floor and half of another in a nondescript office-park building in Wellesley Hills, Mass. In the reception area on the second floor is an antique Ediphone, one of Thomas Edison\'s dictation machines. On a table filled with plaques noting Kurzweil\'s achievements is a photo of him receiving the National Medal of Technology from President Clinton. There\'s a pipe-smoking mannequin with a ribbon that reads "I AM AN INVENTOR" on its chest. In the basement is a supercomputer processing millions of bits of market-related data. Kurzweil is hoping that FatKat will prove to be as spectacular an achievement as his early inventions, only a lot more lucrative. When describing his approach, he refers to the success of fellow MIT board member and hedge fund manager James Simons of Renaissance Technologies, whose $6 billion fund Medallion has averaged 36% returns annually after fees since 1988 and who, according to the hedge fund trade magazine Alpha, was the highest-paid hedgie last

b779348c-c909-4b07-8376-5cec24f084cc.text: The Snoo Sleeper was invented by pediatrician Harvey Karp <https://www.newyorker.com/culture/the-new-yorker-interview/harvey-karp-knows-how-to-make-babies-happy>, who is also the author of a parenting favorite, The Happiest Baby on the Block <https://www.happiestbaby.com/products/the-happiest-baby-book-paperback?pdp-price-comparison=true>. While the features of the Snoo Sleeper such as rocking your baby back to sleep and calming sounds undoubtedly make middle-of-the-night feedings and restlessness more comfortable for parents, the inspiration behind it <https://fortune.com/2021/02/13/snoo-responsive-bassinet-happiest-baby-smart-sleeper-sids-infant-mortality/> was actually to lessen the rate of SIDS-related deaths <https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/sudden-infant-death-syndrome/symptoms-causes/syc-20352800>. SIDS, or sudden infant death syndrome, can occur when a baby rolls onto its stomach during sleep, and 3,400 babies die each year from the condition, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

098270dc-4d4d-43a2-9a32-b5a3a4a20142.text: Hoback makes a brief half-hearted effort to assess if these candidates are Satoshi, and then moves on to Craig Wright <https://fortune.com/crypto/2024/01/25/craig-wright-bitcoin-satoshi-claim-legal-battle/>, an Australian charlatan who arrived on the crypto scene in 2016 with falsified <https://satoshi.nakamotoinstitute.org/posts/bitcointalk/> evidence to claim he invented Bitcoin. Mercifully, the filmmaker is not taken in and moves on to other candidates. As Money Electric progresses, it zeroes in first on Back as a potential Satoshi and then on Back’s Blockstream protégé and friend, Peter Todd.\n\nTodd is much younger than the other figures long identified as likely candidates, and would have been 19 or 20 years old at the time Satoshi Nakamoto published the Bitcoin white paper. To make his case that Todd is Satoshi, Hoback seizes on his 2013 email exchange with an unknown figure named John Dillon about a technical upgrade to Bitcoin.

52ab9e05-30f5-41ef-b77f-c3aaf7eda2f6.text:
Looking ahead, the most significant advancements in AI and other technologies will likely come not from those who invent entirely new concepts but from those who can refine and adapt existing ideas to meet new challenges. Tesla’s success wasn’t in creating the electric vehicle, but in transforming it into something desirable, scalable, and practical. Apple’s triumph wasn’t about inventing the smartphone or the personal computer—it was about making them accessible and indispensable.

True innovation is measured not by where an idea starts, but by how it evolves, how it is improved, and how it transforms industries. The innovators we celebrate should include not only those who popularize ideas but also those who lay the foundations of these breakthroughs. Only by acknowledging this broader network of contributors can we fully appreciate how progress truly happens.

More must-read commentary published by Fortune:

metadata.title: The controversy surrounding AI pioneer Geoffrey Hinton’s Nobel Prize misses the point

701ec465-2df0-4962-a82d-29b346f3d0f5.text:
Artificial intelligence follows a similar path. Hinton’s work was pivotal, but it stood on the shoulders of earlier research. Werbos and Amari’s contributions were critical to the development of neural network techniques that would later power breakthroughs like AlphaGo and OpenAI’s GPT. These technologies didn’t materialize out of thin air—they were the result of decades of incremental progress. Focusing too much on individual figures distorts the reality of technological advancement, which is nearly always a collaborative, multi-layered process.

This brings us to a fundamental truth about innovation: Being the first to develop an idea isn’t as important as being the one who refines, scales, and executes it effectively. Innovation is not about singular genius—it’s about collective progress. When we only credit the most visible figures, we miss the contributions of those who laid the groundwork for breakthroughs.

The controversy surrounding Hinton’s Nobel Prize should spark a reevaluation of how we recognize innovation. Werbos and Amari’s foundational work deserves greater recognition, as their early efforts were critical to enabling Hinton’s advances. Innovation is rarely the product of one person’s genius—it’s a collaborative journey built on incremental improvements over time.

metadata.title: The controversy surrounding AI pioneer Geoffrey Hinton’s Nobel Prize misses the point

492cb63c-19fc-4f8e-ab00-c66bb8bc4e91.text:
and Amari’s 1972 adaptive learning model <https://scholar.google.ca/scholar?q=Shun-Ichi+Amari+1972+adaptive+learning%22&hl=en&as_sdt=0&as_vis=1&oi=scholart> were crucial stepping stones, yet their efforts have largely been overshadowed by the visibility of later figures like Hinton.
The Nobel Prize—the highest honor in science—should recognize the full spectrum of contributions. The oversight in Hinton’s case reflects a broader misunderstanding of innovation itself. The myth of the lone genius, often epitomized by figures like Steve Jobs and Elon Musk, dominates public narratives, leading us to believe that major breakthroughs occur in isolation. In reality, most advances result from cumulative, collaborative efforts. While Hinton’s recognition is deserved, it underscores a common flaw in how credit is distributed: The contributions of early pioneers often fade from view as those who build upon their work take the spotlight.

This is not a problem unique to AI. The history of technology is full of similar stories. Steve Jobs didn’t invent the iPhone from scratch. The iPhone was the product of incremental innovations in smartphones, just as the Macintosh borrowed heavily from innovations developed at Xerox <https://fortune.com/company/xerox/> PARC. Jobs’s brilliance lies in refining these technologies—making them intuitive and accessible to the masses. As Jobs himself admitted, “Good artists copy, great artists steal,” a nod to the reality that innovation often involves improving existing ideas rather than creating something entirely new.

metadata.title: The controversy surrounding AI pioneer Geoffrey Hinton’s Nobel Prize misses the point

d50f7ee6-2aa3-4ffa-8be1-6dd2f0e7a5ef.text: Elon Musk’s association with Tesla <https://fortune.com/company/tesla/> offers another revealing example. Musk joined Tesla in 2004, years after it was founded by Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning. While Musk is often credited with revolutionizing the electric vehicle industry, electric cars have existed for over a century. Musk’s genius wasn’t in inventing electric vehicles—it was in turning the concept into a desirable, scalable, and profitable product. Tesla’s success came not from invention but from relentless execution and refinement, pushing boundaries in battery technology and autonomous driving.\n\nThis dynamic is central to Silicon Valley, where companies routinely build on existing ideas and take them to new heights. Facebook <https://fortune.com/company/facebook/> (now Meta) didn’t invent social networking—MySpace and Friendster had already created the category. Google <https://fortune.com/company/alphabet/> wasn’t the first search engine—AltaVista and others existed long before. What made Facebook and Google succeed was their ability to refine and scale these concepts to global prominence. Silicon Valley’s true strength lies not in creating entirely new technologies, but in improving and expanding existing ones.

metadata.title: The controversy surrounding AI pioneer Geoffrey Hinton’s Nobel Prize misses the point

b407ff35-c4c5-4c38-895f-c67fcd4f4582.text: But how does one invent a word or a phrase, anyway? \n\nWith the flick of a wrist and copious time spent in corner offices, on factory floors, and anywhere else business leaders congregate, Fortune has been generating timeless phrases in our global vernacular for decades. Founded in the wake of the Great Depression, the magazine has persisted through 16 presidents, five contemporary market crashes, and a global pandemic. That makes us just a few months senior to Warren Buffett, the Oracle of Omaha himself, whose popular nickname may even have originated in Fortune—it was bestowed by former Fortune senior editor-at-large Allan Sloan. However, Sloan is pretty sure <https://omaha.com/money/where-did-buffetts-oracle-of-omaha-nickname-start/article_6de32228-828e-535c-a8c9-f3f4d3182103.html> that he coined the moniker while writing a June 1985 article for one of our distinguished competitors.

In Keller the corporation has another Chrysler whose likeness to his prototype is both obvious and reassuring. The fourth member of the dominant group is Fred Zeder

The contenders they might turn into millionaires by pitching their products range from a chemist with a pheromone spray to a pair of brothers with a six-blade disposable razor that dispenses shaving cream from the handle. "Neither of us finished college," says Sullivan, as Mays autographs pictures nearby for a couple of fellow patrons in the bar. "But when it comes to launching a product and getting someone\'s attention and having them say, \'Holy crap, I want to buy that,\' me and Billy are experts. ff4b877d-6ab2-46b3-af02-b197f869134d.txt.LLM_question: What are the best stock picks for 2024?
ff4b877d-6ab2-46b3-af02-b197f869134d.txt.LLM_answer: While it's difficult to pinpoint a single "best" stock pick for 2024, experts and analysts have identified certain trends and companies that could perform well in the coming year. According to Mukherjee, interest rates are likely to fall through the year as the Fed becomes less hawkish and inflation continues to decline alongside moderate economic growth [1]. This could lead to a positive return in the stock market, with some experts anticipating a repeat of the 2023 rally [2].
ff4b877d-6ab2-46b3-af02-b197f869134d.txt.LLM_query: Are there any updates to the best stock picks for 2024?

407aff22-ab12-4336-b1a1-5aa8f17999c3.text:
Americans faced many financial challenges this year, from persistent inflation to increasingly expensive debt. However, the stock market <https://fortune.com/recommends/investing/what-are-stocks/> was one area of the economy that saw improvement. 

After plunging more than 18% in 2022, the S&P 500 rallied over 24% in 2023. (Fun fact: Every time the S&P 500 has fallen more than 18% in a year, it has then posted at least two consecutive years of gains.)

Now the question is: Will this upward trajectory continue into 2024? And how can the average person get the most out of their investments next year? Here’s what experts say about what the stock market might do in 2024.

2024 stock market outlook

metadata.title: Stock market outlook for 2024: Here’s what the experts predict

Additionally, although cash yields are attractive for now, “the appeal of high-quality bonds <https://fortune.com/recommends/investing/what-are-bonds/> will increase as the economy slows, and on better diversification attributes to risk assets,” he adds.\nAnthony Denier, CEO of the trading platform Webull, says he believes the stock market will ultimately post a positive return in 2024 as investors anticipate interest rate cuts by the Fed. However, he adds, we probably won’t see as big of a rally as we did in 2023. “Typically, returns are muted in the last year of a president’s term,” he says.

AI chip supplier Nvidia <https://fortune.com/company/nvidia/> led the index <https://fortune.com/2024/06/05/nvidia-stock-apples-3-trillion-valuation/> with a 239% gain in 2023. Meta and Tesla <https://fortune.com/company/tesla/>, two other tech giants involved in AI, surged 194% and 102%, respectively, last year. Goldman Sachs <https://fortune.com/company/goldman-sachs-group/> estimates that AI investment could reach as high as $200 billion globally by 2025. 

The stock market gains that helped add so many millionaires in 2023 have persisted so far this year as the S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq <https://fortune.com/company/nasdaq/> index hit record highs this week. The S&P 500 is up about 12% year-to-date and some of the biggest players in AI, like Nvidia and Microsoft <https://fortune.com/company/microsoft/>, have seen their shares continue to soar in 2024.

Good morning!

Love them or hate them <https://fortune.com/well/2022/12/24/sheryl-lee-ralph-on-why-shes-ditching-new-years-resolutions-im-not-doing-it-anymore-im-just-gonna-be-my-best/>, New Year’s resolutions offer a chance for anyone to start the year with a clean slate and define their ambitions for the coming months. Business leaders are certainly no exception.

I reached out to the CHROs from 10 companies, including Estée Lauder, Papa Johns, and Walmart, asking them to share their hopes for 2024, and what they plan to focus their energies on. 

Their answers ran the gamut, from providing better support for middle managers, to concentrating on retaining talent. Several themes echoed across resolutions as a whole, including better investment into AI, emphasizing employee wellbeing, and improving employee learning and skills development. 

Cori Davis, the chief people officer at biotechnology company Genentech, took a big picture approach to her resolution, and noted that the last several years have been difficult for everyone. Her goal is to “bring more joy and energy into the workplace.”

The declines come after the S&P 500 hit 38 new all-time highs in 2024, putting the stocks gauge on pace for the second most closing highs in about 100 years, Rubner wrote, adding that only 1995 is shaping up to be stronger.

After that winning streak, stocks are left exposed to the weak inflows and remain vulnerable to negative headlines. There are no predicted inflows in August from passive investors or mutual funds as capital has already been deployed for the third quarter, Rubner said. As for trend-following systematic funds, positioning has reached maximum length, indicating there’s no room for further buying. 

While some investors argue that strong earnings, a possible near-term interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve, and the rising odds of Donald Trump winning the U.S. presidential election would provide another boost for stocks, Rubner says they won’t be positive catalysts. 

Such events are already getting priced into the market and the bar for earnings for the biggest technology stocks that drove market to record highs is remarkably high. “And by high, I mean they need to be great,” he wrote.

a5cb3d6b-38f3-4677-a14d-e371841da054.text: They weren’t even close. When 2000 rolled around, we were working every bit as hard as in the 1960s, and far more of us were working—48% of the population versus 38%. Even so, the economy wasn’t even as big as its minimum projected size in The Year 2000. What went wrong is no mystery. The forecasters extrapolated the previous 20 years of labor productivity growth into the future, but in fact productivity growth slumped deeply. The “productivity paradox” continues and still isn’t well understood, but the lesson is clear: Extrapolating any trend decades into the future is asking for trouble.\n\nSo the Bright Future view of 2000 was wrong—but thankfully the Dark Future view that emerged around 1980 was even further off. That view was summarized in a U.S. government report titled Global 2000. With utter confidence it predicted a colder, hungrier, poorer world of poisoned seas and food wars in the streets. The mortal threat to the planet would be global cooling, not global warming, and America would have to quell food riots, not an obesity epidemic.

A preview: As a work of art, the year was not a minor Buffett. Berkshire—whose shareholders, I wish to say quickly and happily, have long included me—chalked up a $464 million gain in net worth, an advance of no less than 19.5%. That is somewhat below the 23.1% annual average that Buffett has recorded since taking over the company 23 years ago. But in a year in which many professional investors had their heads handed to them, this latest example of Buffett brushwork has to rank as one more masterpiece.
